Fields.DialogueText: So come cheer up my lads, with one heart let us sing; our soldiers, our sailors, our statesmen, our king. Heart of Oak are our ships, jolly tars are our men...
All right, now I know something's wrong.
Hmm? Oh, blimey, Captain, I'm sorry. I was miles away.
Where might that have been?
London. As long as I can still see the lights, part of me's still going to be there.

Fields.MenuText: It's certainly a beautiful city.
Keep your eyes up. The Channel's dangerous.
I'd rather be at sea.

Fields.DialogueText: And if I do say so myself, my eyes are exceptional.
Always. Especially here. Lose the Channel and we lose the Thames.
I know the itch, don't get me wrong. But as itches go, this one's right in the middle of my back.
You're thinking about seeing the city?
Ten metres never felt so far. I'll tell you what I'd like to do, though.
What's that?
Almost. It's more like... like being above the whole world and able to see it perfectly, right down to the cobblestones. But reaching out to touch it? Right out. Glass barrier.
I think I understand. It's like reading everything you can about a place. After a while you feel like you've been there.
Every time we make port. I know it well enough; Belles are like that. But it's not the same as walking through it.
I wish we could get you on land somehow.
The Thames is deep enough. Next time we're in port... I'd like to sail right up to London Bridge. Close enough to manifest and just... walk.
God save the King.
Which you're responsible for guarding.
That sounds beautiful. Saying hello to the people you protect?
Or blending into the crowd. For a moment I can forget I'm a Belle and be an Englishwoman. Another Londoner watching the ships go in and out.
*ALARM*
We'll make it happen, Bulldog. First we've got to make sure there's a bridge to walk on.
One more ship going out, then.
@BATTLE
Ooh! Is that the mail?
A whole bag of it. I thought you'd have some fun going through it.
Scavenger hunt, eh? We're already on one of those. The Morganas have been elusive lately.
You'll be happy to know that's not the case. The whole bag is yours.
Goodness. I knew I was popular, but not this popular.

Fields.MenuText: False modesty doesn't become you.
I did. You're in every newspaper.
You earned it, Bulldog. Be proud.

Fields.DialogueText: Be glad I'm not Hood, Captain. Someone's got to be humble to balance her out.
I try to avoid those. They never quite get all of me.
Right, then. Tonight I'm having two pints of cider.
That's my next few evenings spoken for, then.
Of course I do. I'm not Father Christmas, you know.
For someone who doesn't like the spotlight, you make yourself fairly accessible.
On my terms. I respond, but I keep it to one page and I don't encourage pen pals.
Looks like you've got the biggest family of anyone aboard.
More like neighbours who you can always count on to lend an ear. If the Morganas want to split us up, they'll have to do more than just blast us.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
No shortage of that out here.
Father Christmas doesn't have half the firepower I do.
You don't seriously answer all of these?
Besides, they're writing to a person. If I don't write back, they might as well be praying to the flag. You can imagine my problem with that.
Well, will you look at that?
I see it. Oi! Crowbar here!
Dud Morg shell, eh?
That's our Bulldog for you. It takes more than this to rattle her! Here, stand back while I get this.
Unghhh!
That one did rattle me, incidentally.
I never would have known.
You wouldn't have. I keep my worst language for my worst injuries. It's- ngh.
You can feel them prying it out?
Thank heavens. Like having a big old metal splinter.

Fields.MenuText: ...That must be painful.
I guess getting shot doesn't hurt as much for a Belle.
What if it had gone off?

Fields.DialogueText: Painful, yes. Finite, also yes.
Amazing what a girl can survive. Not that she'd feel like she wanted to, depending.
Varies from Belle to Belle. Some of us bleed. Others burn. I'd prefer not to find out.
*CLANK*
It came out!
Of course it did. This is HMS Bulldog!
That fixed the old shoulder. If only it worked the other way round.
What, like a massage getting rid of a dud shell?
@BATTLE
It'd be immensely satisfying, at least.
Are we going to stand here blushing, or are we going to fight?
*ALARM*
We fight! Of course.
Ugh. The Baltic's looking grim.
What else is new?
It's not totally hopeless. Sweden's turned Gotland into a fortress. But they're the exception and not the rule.
And we Brits think we've got it bad. I'd hate to live in Denmark right now.
Hold on to that hate. We'll be passing through their straits on this tour. Seems the Morganas have found safe harbour somewhere in the Gulf of Bothnia.
And we're to make it unsafe. I can drink to that.

Fields.MenuText: How personal is personal?
I think the crew have those under control.
You certainly stay busy.

Fields.DialogueText: Remember that one spot on my hull that corresponds to my shoulder? Like that.
You try walking around with pebbles in your boots sometime. If I can remove them, I will.
Only way to be, Captain. Besides, it's every engineer's dream to have the ship help with repairs.
Let's see... hmm. Looks pretty standard, except... huh. "Bloody questionable heartburn, recommend second look at third boiler as follows..."
The crew don't have boilers or armour. But they've got bones and organs and the like. I thought it might help bring the point across.
Is it?
So far, so good. No such thing as a rush job in medicine. The more human I can present as, the better the crew can understand me.
Unconventional, but I like it.
*ALARM*
There they are. Any aches I should know about?
@BATTLE
How are repairs coming?
Easier and easier. I've been putting a personal touch on the damage reports. Have a look, won't you?
Convention went out the window as soon as the Morganas broke it.
The sort you get when you've held a fist too long. Let's not waste it.
You don't understand what it's like. I have a family!
You don't need to tell me what that's like. I have eight sisters and eleven half-sisters on the high seas.
If I get killed out here...
You shan't. I won't allow it.
What's going on here?
Oh!
Nothing worth a notice.
By your leave, Captain.
Orders of the day?

Fields.MenuText: That officer seemed scared.
That officer should go home and take care of his family.
Get that coward off my ship.

Fields.DialogueText: He's just anxious about combat. He'll be fine when his nerves settle.
The best way to protect his family is to keep the fight here at sea.
Let me handle that one. He'll be right as rain when the time comes.
We all have to keep our chins up. No shame if they should quiver here and there, but I won't let them fall.
We're only as strong as our weakest link.
I've heard that before, Captain. It's incomplete. We've just as much of a responsibility to him as he to us.
*ALARM*
That's just the kind of people we are.
@BATTLE
... Which, come to consider it, I've a duty still to fulfill. I was a bit hard on him.
Better fulfill it quickly. There's another responsibility bearing down on us.
You've been busy.
Trying to make sense of these charts. Every time I feel like we're close to pinning the Morganas down, they throw us another curveball.
If you wouldn't mind.
Stop.
What do you-
Set it aside. Drink some tea. Then come back to it with fresh eyes.

Fields.MenuText: This could make a serious difference in the war. I can't just drop it.
Maybe you should havea look at it.
I might take you up on that.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not asking you to. It'll be here once the tea's gone.
Give it a teapot. I've just come from being busy.
Brilliant. I'll put the kettle on.
I'm in the same place you are, to tell you the truth. When your own writing stops making sense, there's no use forcing it.
I guess so. I'm not much of a writer.
You don't do it a lot, or you're not very good?
@BATTLE
I guess the former.
Then how do you know if the latter is true?
Need some advice?
I don't. Interpreting information is more my strength. I've thought about going into intelligence after all this is done.
Hmm. Suppose it's not so different from my letters.
It's a little more sensitive than that.
Well, obviously. But you can tell a lot about someone from their small talk. What they fear... what they love... who they are.
It's like a code. If I'm writing to someone back home, it's got a meaning specific to that person and no one else. I may as well send out form letters otherwise.
Sounds like you're running your own morale operation.
We play to our strengths. People seem to like me for what I am. Why not show them who I am in the bargain?
It's not every day a national symbol asks after your family's health.
That it isn't. But I do try.
*ALARM*
Oh, damn. There you go making me forget to put the tea on.
Wouldn't want to leave it steeping in the heat of battle. Besides, I enjoy our talks.
This one isn't over. Count on it.
Damn. This pipe's filthy as a used gun barrel.
Try these.
Pipe cleaners? You're a cherub, Captain. I was fresh out.
Glad I could help.
How did you know I needed more?

Fields.MenuText: Permission to read your mind a bit?
I run a clean ship. That goes for my Belle and her famous pipe, too.
Just a lucky guess.

Fields.DialogueText: Retroactively granted. Suppose it'd help the war effort.
I'm clean as you please. It's this pipe that gives me trouble if I've been distracted lately.
You've a keen eye for those. Keep at it.
It may seem a small thing to you, but I appreciate it. Quite kind.
Get used to it. We should take care of each other.
I shall. It's nice to know someone's looking out for you.
Is something wrong?
No. In fact, I wonder if you-
Captain! Visibility is dropping. Looks like Morganas are on the way.
Thanks, Lieutenant. Get the crew to action stations.
Aye, Captain.
You were saying?
Another time. We've work to do.
@BATTLE
Hmm...
Command's latest reports are in. Looks like our push to the east could go either way.
That's it?
They're still assessing Morgana strength in the Baltic. It is where they first appeared, after all.
And yet there's no maelstrom there. It can't be a centre of power.
Not to that scale, but they're still treading carefully.
Too carefully. If we don't go on the offensive they're just going to regroup and attack in greater strength.

Fields.MenuText: We can't risk it. We can't risk you.
We can mount an impenetrable defense. The cost of breaking it will be too great.
I wish we knew what they were doing.

Fields.DialogueText: We risk me every day. I reckon it's time we shot for a bigger reward.
Morganas don't lose morale and break. They just throw bigger and bigger offensives at us until we do.
Being right sea slags, that's what.
We have to make our little Baltic adventure count, Captain. I'm not leaving the Skagerrak going west until we can say mission accomplished.
I wish that was our decision to make. We just need to figure out what that mission is.
@BATTLE
You're talking to a Royal Navy girl. We write the rules out at sea. Just look at Diamond Rock.
Whatever I need to be, as long as we get to keep our islands.
Is that a naval base?
A ship, legally. The Navy can't own land, so they commissioned an island as a vessel. HMS Diamond Rock. There's more like her in strategic spots around the world.
We may have limitations, but we don't need to play by them. We just need to change the game.
We need to decide what's worth changing. Sweden's trying that with Gotland, but the cost of airlifting everything is ungodly.
So are the Morganas. We just have to be better at it.
Does that make you a demon?
*ALARM*
You mean ships.
Oh, do hush.
Look what we've got here, Captain.
Morganas. I suppose this is as good a welcome as we're getting to Norwegian waters.
I heard the Royal Navy were thinking of mining them before the war began. Something about Germany going for Norwegian iron.
Wouldn't Norway have objected?
Probably. Your point?

Fields.MenuText: It certainly would have come in handy for the Morgana attacks.
What's Norway supposed to do?
It would have been against international law.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, it can't be helped now. We just have to send some more love ourselves.
Lead, follow, or get out of the way. And they haven't the navy for the first one.
So would invading Norway for their iron. There's a larger context to it all.
Proper application of overwhelming force, Captain. That's how you grind your enemies to powder.
Even when people get caught in the crossfire?
@BATTLE
You know-
You get poetic under fire. Were you aware of that?
You do the best you can. But Germany would never have been satisfied, and neither now are the Morganas. We're all on the same team when it comes to starving the beast.
If sacrifices need to be made, we make them or extract them. They can be repaid from the dragon's hoard when it's been slain.
You should hear me when I'm on fire.
Not an invitation, hint, or suggestion.
*ALARM*
The ship's doctor paid me a visit.
We need to keep you healthy, Captain. Everything ship-shape?
Anyway, it's not for me. One of the crew is complaining about a bad back.
Oh. Well, that's less concerning.
It could be serious. We'd need to replace them if that were the case.
Don't give it another thought, Captain. I'll solve this.
What is that supposed to mean?
Bulldog? Where are you going?
@BATTLE
Health initiative, Captain. Don't start the violence without me.
Admit it. You liked it.

Fields.MenuText: Until you subjected me to that, I was.
Nothing that'll keel me.
One more pun like that and I might grant you that offensive you want.

Fields.DialogueText: Play with fire and expect to get burned, Bulldog.
Don't threaten me with a good time, Captain.
Well, if you think you've got a cure-
What do you know about human anatomy?
I'll go make absolutely certain that's not the case, then, shall I?
At least as much as the crew know about Belle anatomy, which by now is quite a lot.
Got the idea from one of my fans. They had a bad back too. Oh, that reminds me-
*ALARM*
Blast. I'll explain later.
Oh? How has she been keeping?
She says her back's never felt better.
Problem solved. On to the next one.
I also spoke to the ship's doctor. He tells me you bent Winthrop over the lifelines and wrenched her back until she said it didn't hurt anymore.
That's right. Anything else to fix before we're ready for the front lines again?

Fields.MenuText: You aren't a doctor, Bulldog.
Don't mistreat the crew.
Thanks for clearing that up.

Fields.DialogueText: I fancy I can pretend well enough.
The minute I do, you may feel free to mothball me.
I'm good for more than just war, you know.
We are needed wherever we can serve. If along the way I see a little kink, I like to un-kink it.
Proper application of overwhelming force, eh? I might have you fix me up sometime.
Aye-aye, Captain.
Accurately.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Blimey, you're starting to sound like the doctor. I'll meet you above.
I had the most interesting conversation with Midshipman Winthrop this morning.
And now I get to hear it from you.
You're smiling. I think you know already.
I respect your initiative, but you don't have to be everywhere at once.
Jolly good! ... That is, of course. If it's necessary.
What was it you wanted to talk to me about earlier, by the way?
Very well. Keep me updated on the rest of the repairs.
I'll tell you when the mail's next in. It's to do with that.
Right full rudder! Keep our left flank away from the guns.
Right full rudder, aye, Captain.
A hot and heavy one, is it?
But not our first, Bulldog. Looks like this group of Morganas wants to pick a fight with us.
Just be a dear and get me in range for biting and head shaking.

Fields.MenuText: Let's do it. All engines ahead flank.
Drive a zig-zag approach. Don't give the Morganas an easy target as we move in.
Open range a bit. We'll catch them off guard when they give chase.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye-aye! Permission to hurl obscenities and explosives at them the whole time, Captain?
Aye-aye. Tenderise before I brutalise.
Making me wait to have my fun? Bold strategy. More frustration to take out on the enemy.
@BATTLE
Granted, Bulldog.
Tea, Captain?
Something strong, if you wouldn't mind. It's going to be a long, sleepless night.
Always useful to see those coming. Well, speaking of things useful, you can help me with this if you're planning on being awake.
Sorting some mail?
Answering some mail. I thought I'd make a ghostwriter of you.
Wait, you're deputising me for your pen pals?
I believe in overwhelming force, but I also believe in efficiency. We'll get these done in half the time once you've got my voice down.
I really think this needs a more personal touch.
And it'll have one. I'll be proofreading your responses like the Ministry of Information.
Maybe make two pots of tea, then. I'm not sure how quick a study I'll be.
We've the whole night ahead of us. You won't see me complaining.
Still taking heavy fire from the Morganas, Captain.
Then let's silence their guns, Officer.
Aye, Captain.
That officer is doing better at keeping a brave face and a steady voice.
I had a talk with him, Captain. I think we understand each other a bit better now.
Better enough to stay in the fight?
To the end. I supported my sisters through Spain's dustup and all the trouble it brought them. He can do the same for his people on the front lines.
And he doesn't even have to be in the newspapers.
As long as you don't-
*BOOM*
*CRASH*
Ouch! Blimey, that was a hard hit. Captain?
Captain, can you hear me?
Ungh!
Damn! You're bleeding all over the place and making a frightful mess.
I'm fine. Just give me a second to-
Don't move.

Fields.MenuText: A little help up?

Fields.DialogueText: Lucky shot, Captain. Let's have the doctor worry about you. I'll handle this.

Fields.MenuText: Not so rough!

Fields.DialogueText: There's no good way to do this, Captain. Bite down on my pipe and we'll get you below.

Fields.MenuText: I'm... I'm fine. I'll walk it off.

Fields.DialogueText: Bollocks. Only I get to do that. Now hold still. I'm in charge now.
Just remember, the mission-
I think he inferred that bit on his own. Avid reader, that one, though there is such a thing as too much news.
Yes, yes, I'm bloody well aware. Cover your ears in the infirmary, Captain. I'm about to make this fight twice as loud.
@BATTLE
I'm also letting him paint the next kill tally on my hull. Nothing like a bit of art to commemorate one's part in a victory.
How are you feeling, Captain?
Bulldog? I was trying to sleep.
It's a good sign that you can.
Well, I appreciate you thinking of me. My side's still tender.
Your injury could have been much worse. And don't move too much - I don't want you popping any stitches. You're quite the bleeder, you know that?
Don't make me laugh. Please don't make me laugh.
I wouldn't dream of it. You're recovering far too nicely.

Fields.MenuText: You must have taken good care of me.
I'm tougher than you think.
I can't have the crew worrying about their captain.

Fields.DialogueText: Did my best. I picked you for command. I'll sink before I let anything un-pick you.
Even I need the occasional stint in dry dock.
I'll do the worrying for them, then. Doctor Bulldog's got a nice ring to it.
*ALARM*
Now, rest up. I'll handle this.
No, Bulldog. I belong on the bridge, not a bed.
Nonsense. You're sleeping through this engagement if I have to knock you out.
I've got no chance of changing your mind, do I?
The nose of the bulldog's slanted backwards so she can breathe without letting go.
Sorted. We'll thank each other later.
@BATTLE
Actually, if you insist on being useful, I've got a whole stack of letters for you to ghostwrite.
That's a no, then. Fine, give me the letters. I'll see what I can write over the din.
You're sitting up. You were sitting up when I left you this morning. That's a good sign.
Is it that time already? I guess I just got lost in the paperwork.
Hmph. Warspite's right. Dying of boredom is a damn sight worse than dying in battle.
No, no, no, I finished the official stuff hours ago. This is your paperwork.
Oh! Let me see.

Fields.MenuText: I tried my best.
How do you stand the responsibility?
I think I've got your voice pretty well in hand.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't think of this as judgment. Like any good war effort, this is a collaboration.
The same way I stand that of protecting the crew and their morale. The civilians just happen to be hundreds of miles away.
You certainly pay attention. Let's see how well that translates to the written word.
Hmm. You've a neglected comma here and there, and the prose could use a little more fire. But you're well on your way to true mimcry.
There's only so many ways I can write "keep calm and carry on."
If it were that easy I wouldn't have deputised you.
And how has being in effective command treated you?
I'm already seeing some of the same-
Swimmingly, I'd say. It's been refreshing to handle these fights myself. I've more opportunities to show off.
It's for the crew's sake, not mine. Anyone can make things explode. The real value's in the doing and the seeing.
You're starting to sound like Hood.
If we're honest, I'm fairly brassed off at the intelligence we keep getting. Plenty of fighting to be had here in the Baltic, but nothing resembling a step forward.
That's really where I'm at with this letter project. Within the limits you set, there's not much room for personalization. And I'm already seeing some of the same people write back.
Inspiration's all well and good, but I'm not a bloody pen pal. We're just going to have to...
... Captain. Repeat what you just said.
*ALARM*
Oh, bugger everything. Captain, you're a genius.
Bulldog, we should-
Ah! A genius in recovery. Leave this battle to me, Captain. I'll need your undivided attention afterward.
@BATTLE
Are you sure about this?
Ninety-nine percent. This should sort the rest of it. What you said about writing to the same people flicked a switch.
We've fought the same Morganas before. Vanity and Corruption and all of them have been sighted the world over. Sometimes more than one in the same place.
Not the same Morganas, Captain. The SAME Morganas. I'm sure I've seen specific copies of our enemies in more than one engagement. They don't clean up perfectly, if I say so myself.
And your solution is to splatter one with paint.
We've plenty of it aboard. I was fairly optimistic when stocking up for the kill tally.
It's simple. We splatter a Morgana and drive her off to repair. If we fight one with red paint on, it'll prove they're just stalling here in the Baltic.

Fields.MenuText: Will it? They could just be playing their cards close to the chest.
You're assuming they won't buff it off.
Stalling for what?

Fields.DialogueText: Try telling Sweden that. Gotland's been under siege since day one.
So we don't use Vanity for our experiment. I know these sea slags, Captain, and their main concern is whether their guns work.
Bloody mystery, that. All the more reason to un-stall them as quickly as possible.
I should have known you'd find a way to get that offensive you've been wanting.
It's not a strike at the enemy's heart, but it's a right crippling rap to the knuckles. Takes the heat off the coasts and gives the people at home something to cheer.
I trust your planning. You're always taking care of us. I've still got the bandages to prove it, see?
And lovely scars besides. Glad you're still with me.
*ALARM*
Morganas! I'll have the crew make the paint round ready.
Even if this doesn't work, it'll be good for a laugh.
@BATTLE
We've still a canvas to find for our paint, but I think the picture will be edifying.
Those are the first casualties of war. Keep them alive and you've a shot at victory.
Captain! Did you see it?
Orders from Command?
They've reported clashes with a Morgana in the Gulf of Riga. You can't see it in the picture, but they're reporting that she was-
Covered in red paint. After we lit her on fire and put her out below the waves of the Kalmar Strait.
That proves it, Captain. They're not replacing their losses. They're repairing them. That means their Baltic forces are finite - and after a scrap, they're immobile.
So they're ordering us back into the thick of things.
This is perfect! Now we just need to smack them down and find out where to stomp.

Fields.MenuText: What must a Morgana shipyard look like?
What are we waiting for? Let's find them.
We need to be on our guard. This could still be a trap.

Fields.DialogueText: Bloody unsettling, but also flammable.
Now that's the kind of initiative I've been looking for!
Everything could be a trap. We've got the opportunity to trap the trappers.
We make best speed for the Gulf of Riga, then. I'll take this report to my cabin and review these orders.
I think this calls for some music, don't you?
Come cheer up, my lads! 'Tis to glory we steer, to add something new to this wonderful year...
@BATTLE
Heh...and maybe a few more after it.
Feel free.
*ALARM*
Fog's thick as day-old porridge out there.
Remind you a little of home?
Most everything does lately. Your hogging of the letters has not helped.

Fields.MenuText: You're just jealous I'm a better you than you are.
This from someone who doesn't need to sleep.
I hope I'm doing them justice.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't you forget which of us has the depth charges.
I am the one keeping us afloat. Always something to be done.
I'm having trouble telling the difference myself. Your prose has come a long way, Captain.
I'll ease off, then. You must be proud of your people. Stiff upper lips, and all that.
That is the idea... but I don't pretend that we can all be stoic in the face of danger. Sometimes just continuing to exist has to be enough.
You know you can tell me if you don't feel up to much more than that.
Hell's bells. Permission to put on an explosive show for the crew?
In perpetuity.
@BATTLE
You'll know the minute I do. You, and nobody else.
That's what I'm here for. You don't have to take care of everything on your own. Even a flag needs something to fly from.
I appreciate it, Captain. Command's made certain that I don't have to fly solo.
Would you really have gone rogue?
Not in my nature. Then again, war teaches you a lot about yourself.
That it does.
Permission to be candid, Captain?
Granted.
Talking of learning about myself... I think, once this war's over, we-
*ALARM*
There's something eerie about these waters.
There's something eerie about all of your waters.
This is different. Do you feel it, too?
Not sure which is worse. The Baltic stinks of Morganas, but the approach to the republics is something else.
Describe it.
Dread. I doubt the people living here are grateful for their proximity to the Wehrmacht or the Reds.

Fields.MenuText: Morganas are always the primary target.
It's no concern of ours.
Been on the lookout for their submarines as well?

Fields.DialogueText: I can't go on land, but I'm not about to ignore it.
I'm sure they know that. It must not help.
Not losing sleep over it... though I budget my time quite effectively.
Well, it's consistent with what I've been seeing on the charts.
Ruhnu. Practically in the centre of the Gulf. I had the navigator chart the escape routes of those Morganas we couldn't sink. Extrapolation takes them north of that island.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
We have 'em. The Morgs don't. I'm quite content for the difference.
Find a common denominator?
Well, what are we waiting for? If their base is there, we go in and smash them up before they can recover.
Granted. You know that's a formality at this stage.
Permission to punish this interruption?
There's Ruhnu. You can just barely see it through the fog.
And north of it... Morganas!
A dozen of them, at least... but they're just sitting there.
Wait. Look at their hulls. See them? They're repairing! Cheating blighters...

Fields.MenuText: Now's our chance. We strike immediately.
There must be more protecting them while they heal.
I hope they're not just playing dead.

Fields.DialogueText: Time to deny them safe harbour once and for all.
The fog's proof enough of that. We wouldn't last half an hour in it without Belles.
They're not above using each other for bait. I'm not letting them catch us unawares.
Wait... Captain, see that?
*ALARM*
Morganas. Looks like we found the guardians.
@BATTLE
That was close. Looks like we've earned the right to be here.
Time to finish the job?
You do it. This requires a personal touch.
Sure. We'll finish them off before your tea gets cold.
You can take the risk. I'm quaffing mine.
Put some tea on. We'll send them all to the bottom right now.
And in bloody good time. Those dormant Morganas are starting to move.
Do the seas seem quieter to you lately?
I thought I was the only one. We've been going longer between Morgana encounters.
I don't like it.

Fields.MenuText: I'd say we've earned a little relaxation.
Sometimes all we can do is wait.
What could the Morganas be planning? Some kind of retaliation?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm relaxing right now, Captain. This is my relaxed face.
There's always something more we could be doing, Captain.
They're petty, Captain... but they're also patient. They can afford to be.
We definitely gave them something to think about. They've been scarce in the Gulf of Riga. Even Gotland's gone a day or two without bombardment.
It's like sailing on the edge of the enemy's side of international waters. There's value in testing their readiness.
Bulldog?
... Captain. Let me have a look at the letters from England. The most recent ones.
What's wrong, Bulldog?
Nothing. Or everything.
*ALARM*
Just the thing to sharpen my teeth on.
@BATTLE
The fog reminds me of home.
What are you talking about?
Closer to everything than nothing. Looks like a straggler patrol.
Can't we go any faster?
You're the ship, Bulldog. You tell me.
Thirty-five knots. Might as well be three and a half.
Hand me those binoculars. The fog is getting thick.
Keep them. You need them more than I do.

Fields.MenuText: We'll get there when we get there, Bulldog. No sooner.

Fields.DialogueText: Cold comfort for the people we've been chatting with.
I can't believe I didn't see the warnings earlier. When the letters talked about the fog-
It's England, Captain. There's always bloody fog. But when it hangs around the way it's been... we've seen what it can hide. The Morganas are building another Ruhnu in the North Sea.
Striking distance of London. So the Baltic was a ruse.
It wasn't a bloody ruse. There's just too damn many of them and too few of us.
*ALARM*
Case lodged firmly and uncomfortably in point.
You said before you weren't going to leave the Skagerrak until we could say mission accomplished. It looks like our mission's taking us that way.
Quite so.
Proper application of overwhelming force, then?
It's like you read my mind.
Let's say I've had some practice with it.

Fields.MenuText: What do you see?
I'm keeping my eyes out for any interference.

Fields.DialogueText: I see a whole load of open ocean that we're on the wrong sodding side of.
It had better be enough. I've scented blood and they're going to be sniffing about for ways around me.
@BATTLE
Letter from Newcastle. Wallsend shipyard's been fighting for its life.
Stay on target, Bulldog. London's our priority.
Right. There's home and then there's home.
There's just got to be a home to save.

Fields.MenuText: None of that. We're coming to London's defense and the Morganas won't know what hit them.
I believe in you. So does everyone we've written to.

Fields.DialogueText: They will, Captain. I'm burning my memory into whatever awful intelligence controls them.
My thoughts precisely, Captain. You've gotten good at phrasing them.
Permission to sing loudly and boisterously while we fight for our lives, Captain?
Would it matter if I said no?
You know how bulldogs work. We're built to bite down and never let go.
We ne'er see our foes but we wish them to stay...
Heart of oak are our ships, Jolly Tars are our men! We'll always be ready! Steady, boys, steady!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Time to put your money where your mouth is.

Fields.DialogueText: Always wanted to spit shillings at one of these beasties.
They never see us but they wish us away...
And you'll find the crew are on my side.
Our side.
The winning side.
*ALARM*
That's the closest to London they're going to get.
Looks like they're settling for that. They've set up a blockade for us.
How thoughtful of them.
The only way out of here is through that line.
Forming a proper wall of nasty ships, they are.
So many, lined up like bowling pins.
Think we can knock them all down?

Fields.MenuText: If you want to London's streets to be safe, that's what it takes.
I'd rather be the ball than the pin any day.
A steel goddess and her captain? We can't lose.

Fields.DialogueText: Then we lock on unto death. Ours or theirs.
Then a proper strike it is!
Oh, I think I shan't ever tire of hearing that.
@BATTLE
That's the last we'll see of them.
Not the last, Captain. But they'll think twice about hitting the Channel in force from now on.
Of course they will. You'll always be here to defend it.
After a fashion. I'll be wherever Command choose to send us.
You think they'd take you away from your home?
Bulldog...
I suppose that makes the letters a home away from home.
As long as I'm defending it, that's enough for me.
Then it's enough for me too. Wherever you are is...
Nothing ever could, Captain. I was never truly there to begin with.
Don't look so grim. I've better things to do than mope about reality.
To be English every way but in England herself... well, if I could drag this hulk across the Cotswolds, I'd do it in a heartbeat.
But she's more than just an island. She's the Empire, and her waters, and the people who walk along them knowing they're safe beneath her flag.
... Yes. That.
Along London Bridge, watching the ships go out.
Is?
... England.
Right. Of course, Captain.
Enjoying the view up there, Bulldog?
To be candid, I was hoping you'd turn up. Sit next to me.
In a minute. Listen, I know you can't go ashore with everybody else. I might have a solution.
Come on. Let me show you something.
The view's too lovely.
This one's better. Promise.
I reserve the right to blow smoke in your face if that's not true.
Almost... almost... all right, open your eyes.
Captain, what on earth...?
I doubled some rum rations to get the crew to scrounge this all up.
A table and chairs... oh, is that roast beef?
Piping hot. With a couple of pints of cider to wash it down. If you'll just walk across these...
Bits of... tarmac? What's the game here, Captain?
One of your fans happens to be a road worker. Guess where they've been doing some repairs.
... Captain, you didn't!

Fields.MenuText: It cost a bit to ship the pieces here, but I'm reimbursing him. Matter of state security.
And before you ask, it hasn't fallen down. Just routine maintenance.
I thought you could use some practice walking on London Bridge. Get your land legs.

Fields.DialogueText: London Bridge... You've got me in a secure state, all right.
Nor will it ever, if we've anything to say about it. I've a feeling we do.
I... Captain, I don't know where to begin!
Until you can walk down London's streets... well, we don't know when that might be. But until then, we'll just bring London to you.
Thank you, Captain. I've never seen something so... so...
Come on. We don't want the roast beef to get cold.
It's bloody marvelous. There, that's sorted.
You're sitting on the other side of the table?
Is there a problem?
Well... you can move closer if you like.
Thank you. I think I'll take you up on that.
Let me help you with... right. There's a love.
Er... that is, there's-
No, no, that was fine. Permission granted.
Indefinitely?
Definitely indefinitely. I've never met someone quite like you, you know.
I'd advise against doing it again. I'm not the sharing type.
How do bulldogs work again? Something about not letting go?
Got it in one.
